These are sample sets as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Rain Setter
sets.description:

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Tailwind Setter
sets.description:

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Bulky Utility
sets.description:
• The given EV spread and nature retains enough Attack for Hippowdon to OHKO Chi-Yu with Stomping Tantrum before investing remaining EVs in HP and Special Defense.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

Amoonguss.overview: Amoonguss is the tier’s premier redirector, sustaining its teammates with Pollen Puff and neutralizing foes with Spore. Its defensive prowess, coupled with Regenerator, provides it the sustainability to soak up hits while supporting its team. Due to its effectiveness, Amoonguss finds itself on a large variety of team styles, from Trick Room to hyper offense. Setup attackers such as Nasty Plot Gholdengo and Swords Dance Iron Hands appreciate its redirection and healing capabilities, and they make up for its near-nonexistent offenses. Amoonguss's Grass / Poison typing provides resistances to key attackers such as Palafin-H and Iron Hands but leaves it weak to Fire- and Ice-types like Chi-Yu and Chien-Pao. Further, its passivity diminishes its utility against status-immune Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Garganacl. Finally, opposing Grass-types such as Meowscarada, Abomasnow, and Tera Grass Iron Hands and Safety Goggles users such as Farigiraf and Sylveon are immune to Amoonguss's Spore and Rage Powder, invalidating its support options.
Amoonguss.comments:
Other Options

With Covert Cloak, Amoonguss can turn the tables on Fake Out users and put them to sleep as well as reliably check Garganacl by ignoring its Salt Cure. Rocky Helmet punishes contact attackers such as Dragonite and Palafin-H and KOes Maushold after 8 hits of Population Bomb. Occa Berry allows Amoonguss to survive a Heat Wave from Choice Specs Chi-Yu and Eruption from Charcoal Torkoal. Eject Button can be used to switch into or redirect an attack and then pivot to a frail attacking teammate. None of these items complement Amoonguss's bulk as well as Sitrus Berry, however. Clear Smog allows Amoonguss to check setup foes such as Swords Dance Iron Hands and Iron Defense Garganacl. Foul Play can be used to hit strong physical attackers such as Choice Band Dragonite and Garchomp.

sets.name: Redirection Support
sets.description:
• Spore dissuades foes from staying in and prevents them from setting up Trick Room. If Trick Room ends up active, Amoonguss can utilize its low Speed to threaten foes with sleep.

  • Rage Powder enables teammates to set field conditions such as Trick Room or Tailwind safely.

  • Pollen Puff heals teammates and damages foes in a pinch, notably OHKOing Meowscarada.

  • Leaf Storm is Amoonguss’s biggest source of damage, OHKOing Iron Bundle, 2HKOing Palafin-H, and pressuring the sleep-immune Garganacl. Protect is useful in scouting foes’ moves, blocking Fake Out, and improving overall survivability.

  • Regenerator allows Amoonguss to come into the field and absorb attacks repeatedly.

  • The EV spread allows Amoonguss to survive two consecutive Make It Rains from Choice Specs Gholdengo after Sitrus Berry.

  • 28 Speed IVs allow Amoonguss to underspeed Iron Hands and Kingambit under Trick Room.

  • Tera Water turns Amoonguss's Fire- and Ice-type weaknesses into resistances and is overall a great defensive typing. It also removes its Flying-type weakness, further improving its matchup against rain teams.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• The given EV spread and nature allow Tsareena to outspeed Iron Bundle under Tailwind, retain enough Attack to OHKO 252 HP Palafin-Hero with Power Whip, then invests the remaining EVs in HP.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

sets.name: Dual Screens
sets.description:
• The given EV spread and nature allow Grimmsnarl to survive a Swords of Ruin-boosted Extreme Speed from a Choice Band Tera Normal Dragonite, then invests the remaining EVs into Special Defense.

This is a sample set as we work on proper analyses. Stay tuned!

Garganacl.overview: With solid defenses and access to reliable recovery, Garganacl can perform well in a utility role or with setup in Iron Defense. Its biggest selling points are its unique move and ability: Salt Cure offers valuable passive damage, synergizing well with its natural bulk, while Purifying Salt provides a useful immunity to status moves such as Spore and Toxic. Garganacl is difficult to break for many Pokemon, but it matches up notably well into Fire-types such as Chi-Yu and Arcanine, Flying-types like Dragonite and Iron Jugulis, and Amoonguss due to Purifying Salt. As one of the best Wide Guard users, Garganacl can block the format's many powerful spread attacks such as Gholdengo's Make It Rain, Chi-Yu's Heat Wave, and Armarouge's Expanding Force. Iron Defense lets Garganacl play as a potent wincon instead, increasing its Defense whilst simultaneously strengthening its offensive presence through Body Press. These sets can be very difficult to take down, though they often rely on using up Terastallization to be most effective. Garganacl's abysmal Speed means it will usually be relegated to moving last. Rock typing also leaves Garganacl with countless weaknesses, including to Water-, Steel-, and Fighting-type moves, meaning common Pokemon such as Palafin, Gholdengo, Iron Bundle, Iron Hands, and Great Tusk all significantly threaten it. Amoonguss is one of the best partners for Garganacl, being helpful against several of the aforementioned threats, while Garganacl checks Fire-types like Chi-Yu in return, with redirection support and healing being especially critical for Iron Defense sets. Garganacl also appreciates teammates that can check Gholdengo, especially if not using Wide Guard, so Pokemon like Chi-Yu, Arcanine, Ting-Lu, and Kingambit are other desirable additions.
Garganacl.comments:
Other Options

Other defensive Tera types are also usable depending on team needs. For example, Tera Poison still provides a Fighting-type resistance but doesn't gain the Dark-type weakness that Tera Ghost does. This means after Terastallization, Garganacl will still be good against Chi-Yu and gains immunity to Toxic Spikes, at the cost of not losing its Ground-type weakness. Tera Water is another alternative, offering helpful resists against Water-types like Palafin and Steel-types like Gholdengo.

sets.name: Bulky Utility
sets.description:
• Salt Cure forms Garganacl's offensive presence, dealing insignificant damage directly but leaving a powerful residual effect that lasts even after Garganacl leaves the field.

  • Recover complements Garganacl's bulk, allowing it to outheal most attacks while Salt Cure passively whittles down foes.

  • Wide Guard stops powerful spread attacks such as Make It Rain, Heat Wave, Expanding Force, and Earthquake. Stealth Rock alternatively offers chip damage throughout the match, breaking Focus Sashes and punishing attempts to remove Salt Cure's effect through switches.

  • Protect lets Garganacl rack up Leftovers recovery and Salt Cure damage. This is especially effective against the Water- and Steel-types that threaten Garganacl, as they take increased damae from Salt Cure's effect.

  • The given EV spread and nature patch up Garganacl's lower Special Defense, making it difficult to break through with both physical and special attacks, which is further aided by Leftovers for even more healing.

  • Purifying Salt provides an invaluable immunity to Amoonguss's Spore and a notable resistance to Gholdengo's Shadow Ball, which assists in stalling it out with Wide Guard.

  • Tera Ghost turns Garganacl's weakness to Fighting-types like Iron Hands and Great Tusk into an immunity, effectively leaving it with a single weakness with Purifying Salt.

sets.name: Iron Defense
sets.description:
• Salt Cure provides passive damage, which is especially useful on this set for Pokemon that resist or are immune to Body Press, such as Gholdengo and Amoonguss.

  • Iron Defense makes Garganacl even more difficult to knock out, while Body Press lets the boosts double as an offensive bonus too.

  • Recover enhances Garganacl's staying power, increasing its effectiveness as a wincon.

  • EVs and nature are used to maximize special bulk, as Iron Defense covers the physical side. Leftovers tops out Garganacl's survivability with some passive healing.

  • Purifying Salt confers immunity to Spore and prevents a traditional form of setup counterplay in Toxic.

  • Tera Ghost gives a valuable Fighting-type immunity, notably including Sacred Sword, which will ignore the Defense boosts, and leaves Garganacl with effectively just one weakness in combination with Purifying Salt.

sets.name: Bulky Attacker
sets.description: • The given EV spread, nature and Assault Vest allow Iron Bundle to survive a ruin-boosted Overheat from Chi-Yu and OHKO it in return with Hydro Pump while retaining enough speed to move before Meowscarada. Incidentally, the spread also allows Iron Bundle to survive a ruin-boosted Extreme Speed from a Choice Band Tera Normal Dragonite.

Iron Hands.overview: Iron Hands is a slow but exceptionally bulky and strong physical attacker, as well as one of the best Fake Out users in the tier. It fits best on Trick Room teams that benefit from its low Speed but also has enough bulk to compensate for its slowness and perform adequately on any team that appreciates the safe turns that Fake Out can provide. Iron Hands most commonly holds an Assault Vest to patch up its lower Special Defense stat and comfortably endure and trade attacks with its enemies. Another popular set foregoes Assault Vest to enable the use of Swords Dance, turning Iron Hands into a fearsome setup sweeper. With either set, Iron Hands is a reliable and well-rounded Pokemon that matches up decently into much of the metagame, although it does need to be wary of a few commonly encountered threats. Amoonguss, the tier's most common and bulkiest redirector, walls both of Iron Hands's STAB attacks and can survive two of its Ice Punches. Despite Iron Hands's massive bulk, a few especially hard-hitting Pokemon like Great Tusk and Armarouge have the offensive capability to break through it with ease. Finally, Iron Hands needs to be wary of priority blockers like Farigiraf, Indeedee-F, and Tsareena when using Fake Out.
Iron Hands.comments:
Other Options

Iron Hands can be made even bulkier by shifting some or all of its Attack EVs into HP and Defense. Moving 64 EVs into HP allows the Assault Vest Iron Hands set to survive two boosted Shadow Balls from Modest Nasty Plot Gholdengo, as well as one Overheat from a Tera Fire Choice Specs Chi-Yu. In addition to the 64 HP EVs, an additional 48 EVs can be moved into Defense to allow Iron Hands to survive two Extreme Speeds or Dragon Claws from Tera Normal Choice Band Dragonite, as well as one Headlong Rush from Adamant Great Tusk. Iron Hands can also invest 124 EVs in Speed to outspeed Garchomp under Tailwind but should retain at least 100 Attack EVs and an Adamant Nature when doing so to ensure Ice Punch OHKOes Garchomp. Tera Fire can be used to prevent burns from Will-O-Wisp users like Arcanine while also providing a STAB boost to Fire Punch. Heavy Slam can be run as a coverage move if Fairy-types such as Sylveon are a concern. Finally, Belly Drum can be used in place of Swords Dance as a higher-risk, higher-reward Attack-boosting move, but losing 50% HP in the process is a high price to pay for a Pokemon that prides itself on its bulk and longevity. When using Belly Drum in combination with a Sitrus Berry, ensure that Iron Hands's HP stat is an even number so that Sitrus Berry activates after the 50% HP drop.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
• Fake Out is a high-value utility move that creates safe turns for partners to provide speed control, boost stats, switch out, or attack.

  • Close Combat is Iron Hands's strongest available STAB move and can inflict massive super effective damage on several top-tier Pokemon such as Iron Bundle, Ting-Lu, and Chi-Yu. It has the unwelcome (repetition) side effect of lowering Iron Hands's highly desirable bulk, however. Drain Punch can be run instead as a weaker alternative that provides healing.

  • Wild Charge and Thunder Punch are secondary STAB moves that are useful for hitting Pokemon with an immunity or resistance to Close Combat, such as Gholdengo and Armarouge, as well as Pokemon weak to Electric-type attacks such as Palafin and Gyarados. Wild Charge provides a higher damage output than Thunder Punch at the expense of recoil damage, and either option is valid depending on personal preference.

  • Ice Punch stops Iron Hands from being completely walled by Amoonguss while also hitting Garchomp and other Ground-types for super effective damage. Alternatively, Drain Punch can be run in this slot as a secondary Fighting-type STAB attack and used when Close Combat's drawbacks aren't worthwhile, while Volt Switch is useful to pivot out of an unfavorable matchup or to safely switch in a partner.

  • The given EV spread with an Adamant nature prioritizes maximizing Iron Hands's Attack before using the remaining EVs and an Assault Vest to patch up its lower Special Defense. A Brave nature with 0 Speed IVs is sometimes preferable when using Iron Hands as a Trick Room attacker, but either way just be aware that an Adamant nature makes Iron Hands faster than Ting-Lu, while a Brave nature makes it slower.

  • Tera Grass provides an immunity to Amoonguss's Spore and Rage Powder as well as a resistance to Ground-type attacks that Iron Hands is otherwise weak to. Tera Fighting can be used instead to boost Iron Hands's offensive presence, notably guaranteeing an OHKO versus standard Ting-Lu sets with Close Combat.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
• Swords Dance boosts the damage output of Drain Punch and Thunder Punch to highly threatening levels. This move is especially useful for punishing opponents who play passively in anticipation of a more conventional set, which is inclined to click its STAB attacks or Fake Out immediately.

  • Drain Punch is preferred over Close Combat on this set, since Iron Hands has access to Swords Dance to increase Attack and would rather take advantage of the HP recovery that boosted Drain Punches can provide.

  • Thunder Punch is a secondary STAB attack that hits Pokemon with an immunity or resistance to Drain Punch, such as Gholdengo and Armarouge, as well as Pokemon weak to Electric-type attacks such as Palafin and Gyarados. Fire Punch can be run instead to prevent Iron Hands from being walled by Amoonguss while also hitting Gholdengo for super effective damage, at the cost of leaving Iron Hands without an effective move to hit Armarouge with.

  • Protect is the preferred final move on this set for teams that want to make full use of Iron Hands's potential as a setup sweeper with longevity. Fake Out can be run instead to provide safe turns for Iron Hands's partners to move.

  • The given EV spread and Adamant nature prioritize maximizing Iron Hands's Attack before using the remaining EVs to patch up its lower Special Defense. A Brave nature and 0 Speed IVs are sometimes preferable when using Iron Hands as a Trick Room attacker, but either way just be aware that an Adamant nature makes Iron Hands faster than Ting-Lu, while a Brave nature makes it slower.

  • Tera Grass provides an immunity to Amoonguss's Spore and Rage Powder as well as a resistance to Ground-type attacks that Iron Hands is otherwise weak to. Tera Flying is an alternative option that offers full immunity to Ground-type attacks at the expense of powder move immunity, but this can be patched up with Safety Goggles, which is the preferred item for Tera Flying Iron Hands.
